review_title: Not for everyone, not for most.
pros: Compensation including RSU is generally higher than most other companies. There are occasionally opportunities to work on projects that might impact business trajectory or customer experience. There are some people you’ll meet who are incredibly smart and top of their respective fields. Depending on manager there is flexibility in time off or needing to have appointments, work from home, etc.
cons: Internally it’s like walking a mine field. Internal technologies and programs lag most public companies with most everything being housed only in spreadsheets. It’s become incredibly political with vast differences in where the performance “bar” lies depending on your demographic. I mentioned projects above but you’ll mostly be so buried in administrative tasks that you won’t have time or you’ll compromise quality just to fit it into your schedule. A minimum of 60 hours a week is a clear expectation with more during “busy” times which seems to be all the time. Expect late nights and frequent weekend work. Management is just as saddled as junior employees so there is little direction or development, taking trainings or learning a new skill is unrealistic. Majority of analysts are fresh off their MBA with little to no work experience but very full of themselves because of alma mater. Overall churn is super high so you’re rarely building relationships with your teammates as most won’t be there in 6 months. Creates churn on work too, half the team doesn’t really know their responsibilities or how to execute on them. A lot of people have drank the kool aid so you are expected to ignore the cons and only talk about how great the company is and how everyone working there is the smartest in the world.

job_title: Software Development Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros:
- You will never be not busy.
- Potential for quick growth and interesting problems
- Stock appreciates well
cons:
- You will never be not busy. 
- What you learn really depends on how senior the members on your team are and what you team is doing. Many team are KTLO teams where you learn nothing.
- Oncall is bad and 24/7, no extra benefits
- Amazon benefits are F tier for a company of it's market cap. Free banana? No holiday parties, no team events, just work, 2% match, minimal annual raise 
- Don't expect to a get a significantly more amount of stock from your initial grants
- No target bonuses or stock grants or raises if stock is doing well (always is) so aka never getting more stock past your initial grant.
- Vesting schedule back loaded so they can fire you before you vest anything.
- Mandatory stack ranking.
- Performing well barely gets you a raise. 
- Frugality to the point of stupidity. Frupidity
- Despite the LP don't disagree and commit with your manager. Your manager at any time can ruin your career at Amazon and PIP you. They just need a couple of nitpicks to start the process, doesn't matter if you are excelling.
- Very bureaucratic culture, with useless manager's needing to approve everything.
- Everything is done SDEs
- Very tight deadlines set by PMs.

job_title: Warehouse Associate in Las Vegas, NV
pros: It's a paycheck. A possible "pro" is that during peak (holidays) they have mandatory overtime. My schedule was a mandatory 5 days/week AND 12 hours per day. Regular full time for them is 4 days at 10 hours.
cons: Environment (not nearly cool enough for how demanding the job is), quotas, you can end up walking 7-12 miles a day (break rooms are scattered, so a 15 minute break can turn into a 7 minute break with walking time). They are just extremely demanding, and it's very rough for someone who's not expecting it. I found it hard to get answers from higher management and HR, and I was kept on as a "seasonal" employee (which meant NO benefits (so getting sick or injured was NOT an option) and no chance for growth) for the entire time I was there.
